That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: âI rise in this grievance debate to mention a couple of matters of great concern to me. The first matter that I want to bring to the attention of the House is the plight of one of my constituents, Mr Noel Bourne, whose home at Alexandra Hills was subjected to forced entry by two juveniles. The two offenders were apprehended after spending four days in Noel Bourne's home. But, while they were on the premises, the pair fraudulently logged up telephone calls to the value of $9,329.51 to the 1900 service. You can imagine my constituent's dismay when he received accounts from both Telstra and Optus requesting payments for $6,674.15 and $2,655.36 respectively. In good faith, he approached both Telstra and Optus and explained the circumstances behind these extraordinarily large bills. Optus compassionately waived the $2,655.30 owing, and for this I must extend, on behalf of Mr Bourne and his family, my appreciation and thanks.

speech.para: Telstra, on the other hand, have pursued the debt and are threatening legal action to collect the outstanding debt, even though they have established the nature and the validity of the calls. My constituent is a battler with four young children. There is no way he could afford to pay this amount, yet Telstra remain unrepentant, even suggesting that Mr Bourne's insurance would cover the cost of the fraudulent calls. It does not.

They go further to recommend that he should have perhaps put on a temporary suspension network barring and easy call control, which would have mitigated my constituent's exposure to some of this debt. I would ask: what percentage of ordinary Australians have these facilities or even know that all these facilities exist? Even officers of the Consumer Affairs Division of Treasury have been unable to resolve my constituent's dilemma. Surely, there should be some protection for consumers in instances such as this where clearly there has been fraudulent use of their telephone service.

On 28 May 1999, I made representations to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Richard Alston, requesting that he intervene on behalf of my constituent and show some compassion for the circumstances Mr Bourne and his family have found themselves in. Have we heard back from the minister? No. This is despite a further reminder to him on 2 August 1999. Telstra should show some compassion and do the same thing as Optus. I ask the question, given that today Telstra listed on the Stock Exchange: what are they going to be like if the government gets its way and privatises them altogether? I ask Telstra to reverse their decision and show some consideration for my constituent.

While we are talking about compassion, I want to bring up another matter which I think needs to be brought up, particularly in view of a dorothy dixer that was asked in the parliament today of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. I refer to the question of the number of Kosovar refugees who are still here. All members of this House will remember that, some months ago, we involved ourselves in an enormous humanitarian operation. At the time, it was a bipartisan thing, and it still is. I heard just about all of the speeches, and I personally welcomed the first arrivals from the European camps along with the Prime Minister and the minister for immigration.

I cannot recall the Kosovars being told anywhere in speeches made by the Prime Minister and the minister that, if they overstayed their welcome, they would be in breach of the Migration Act and would be forcibly deported. But I will get to that later. Over ensuing months, the outpouring of support continued from all sections of the community, fuelled by the government's assurances of safety to these poor people. The government emphasised that these people were now safe and that they could count on Australia's hospitality and protection for as long as it took.

All in this House knew, however, that our official hospitality had already been set in concrete by legislation for a period of some three months, with a possible extension of a mere three months. The Labor Party, in spite of our in-principle support for the humanitarian operation, urged the government to be generous in the way that they handled that this very major exercise. I spoke about this in a number of press releases in April and, later, in August. Under the heading, Kosovo refugee `pause'âLabor says Australia should reaffirm its commitment, I said on 10 April:

In the event that a resolution is reached, I call upon the Government to make a commitment to expand, on a one-off basis, the annual permanent refugee intake to cater for those who have become politically vulnerable and in fear of their lives should they return to Kosovo.

The Government need only to look at what Labor did while in Government to assist the plight of refugees from Bosnia-Herzegovina in 1995. On that occasion, 2000 extra refugees were added to the normal annual intakeâborrowed from the forward program.
Again, a press release of Tuesday, 24 August 1999 stated:

Mr Sciacca said that while parts of Kosovo are now relatively safe, almost 1000 refugees are from Eastern Kosovo, which following the redrawing of national boundaries by NATO is still under Serbian influence.

`The Federal Opposition has been saying for many months that some of these people would want to remain in Australia and that those who had a proven fear of persecution upon their return should be allowed to apply for refugee status.

`For the umpteenth time, the Opposition calls on the Government to amend the Kosovo Safe Haven legislation to allow those Kosovars who fear for their safety should they return to be allowed to state their case.

`Allowing the Kosovars to apply for refugee status will safeguard their safety while at the same time removing them as a burden on the public purse, giving them a chance to become productive members of the Australian community,' Mr Sciacca said.

Time and time again, the opposition has stated publicly that a few hundred Kosovars would want to remain because of well-founded fears of persecution if they were forced to return to their homeland. Some of these people, as I said in the press release, are from a part of Kosovo that is still under Serbian control. I cannot think of a better reason to be generous and compassionate towards these people. We are not talking about thousands of them but rather a few hundred. We allow 12,000 refugees in every year. Even if all of these who want to stayâapproximately 400 or 500âcould prove that they were refugees and even if all of them stayed, they would be only something like four per cent or five per cent of our total refugee intake. In fact, it would be a minuscule half of one per cent of our total immigration intake of 86,000.

In comparison, the United States, whom we try to emulate in so many ways, has guaranteed permanent residency to their Kosovar refugees. In addition, if their refugees choose to go back to their homeland and then return within a year, the US government will still grant them permanent residency. Obviously, we have much more to learn about compas sion. Instead, our government's approach is to remove these people against their wishes and the wishes of the communities in which they live, especially Tasmania and South Australia. I acknowledge Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, who has just taken the chair, who has been taking their side with my full support and that of the opposition, irrespective of the abuse he is getting from Senator Abetz, who would not know if it were Christmas or New Year's.

Firstly, the government encouraged the public campaign aimed at hardening the hearts of the same people they tried to win over a few months earlier with speeches about Australia's responsibility to help those who are less fortunate. Stories of Kosovar refugees stealing furniture, destroying equipment and smearing faeces on the wall of safe havens were stories of the actions of a few who are probably still disturbed, traumatised and frightened by their experiences. These stories are designed to shed darkness on all the Kosovars and their so-called disgraceful behaviour.

Secondly, when the government felt public opinion shifting against the Kosovars, the minister flew to Tasmania, where the refugees were dangerously close to being accepted and adopted by the community. The front page of the Hobart Mercury says `Five months ago Tasmanians made them welcomeâyesterday Ruddock told Kosovos go home'. Have a look at this: it is disgraceful. He tells them to go home, and then went on to say in the same publication:
`I don't want it to come to this but if people become unlawful, they may have to be taken into detention and removed from Australia . . .
`That's the law and at the moment, unless I extend their visas on the 30th October, they become unlawful.'

It is clear that, where people can be forcibly removed, that will occur. Essentially what he has said is, `We don't want you anymore. Go home now or I will arrest you and deport you.' He reiterated that stance today in answer to a dorothy dixer. This is nothing more than compassion with a use-by date.
Senator Andrew Bartlett said something very relevant the other day in a press release. He said:
The Prime Minister was there welcoming the refugees when they landed in Australia. Will he be there waving them goodbye when they are forcibly deported?

The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs prides himself on being a fair and compassionate personâa champion of human rights and the plight of refugeesâyet the minister chose Refugee Week to tell a couple of hundred traumatised Kosovars that they are no longer welcome. How compassionate is that? I acknowledge that as politicians we have to temper our compassion with political judgment; however, there are lines that should not be crossed, and there are times when compassionate generosity should be unreserved and unconditional. This is one of those times.

I fail to see the reason why we have thrown $100 million plus down the toiletâthat is what we have spent on those people so farâby not allowing 300 or 400 of these people to stay here. I call on the government to allow these Kosovars to state their case for refugee status under the current guidelines and, if their fears are substantiated, to let them rebuild their lives in this country that they so desperately want to be a part of. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âJust over a week ago I finalised a list of successful recipients of the recognition awards for older Australians. I was also present in Canberra for the presentation of the Older Australian of the Year award. These occasions are a wonderful inspiration. It was fantastic to see the enthusiasm, the vitality and the energy of people in their 70s, 80s and even 90s who have a real desire to learn, are still thrilled by new experiences in life and have a real zest for living.

speech.para: It was also really encouraging to see the immeasurable contribution of these retirees and these older persons to our community and to the lives of others in their roles as volunteers, as carers and as members of groups such as Lantern, Legacy, CWA, Red Cross, hospital auxiliaries, Probus, Meals on Wheels and other support organisations that put in so many voluntary hours for the good of others in the community.

Over the past three years it has been a privilege to meet so many older Australians in the Blue Mountains and the Hawkesbury communitiesâpeople who are selflessly committed to the wellbeing of others and who give so much of themselves to improve the lives of others and who play an invaluable role in the life of our community. The recognition of the International Year of Older Persons provides an excellent opportunity to recognise the contribution of older Australians. It is also an important time to remind ourselves of the growing challenges of an ageing demographic and the need to make long-term plans adequately, first of all, so we can maximise the benefits of the contribution of older citizens to our community and, secondly, to ensure that we can adequately meet their needs. This is a challenge not only for Australia but for most of the OECD countries. In Australia there are currently 2.2 million people who are over the age of 65âthat is, 12 per cent of our population. Within 20 years that will rise to four million, or 18 per cent of our population. Within 50 years it will rise to 6.3 million, or 26 per cent of our population. We now have half a million people over the age of 80, which is 2.8 per cent of our population. This will rise within 30 years to more than one million, which is 4.5 per cent of our population.

As this ageing process occurs, so the age dependency ratio risesâthat is, the number of retirees per working-age person who can support them. Those age dependency ratios are estimated to rise from the current level of 18 per cent to some 40 per cent within the next 50 years. Conversely, the number of people working to support each retiree will fall from 5.6 to 2.5 in that same period. This is a measure of the difficulty there will be to adequately provide an income support level for our older Australians.

There are a number of challenges involved with an ageing community, and two of them I want to pursue in a little more detail. The first is the challenge to provide an adequate income support level to our older citizens. It is essential that we guarantee adequate living standards. This cannot be done by the pension alone. The OECD estimates that age and related pensions will rise from three per cent of GDP in Australia to 4Â½ per cent by the middle of the next century. Therefore, it is essential that we do what we can to encourage self-sufficiency.

Certainly it is essential that we do what we can to provide for those who are on the pension, and this government have already begun to do that. We have indexed age pensions to a minimum of 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. We have raised the tax-free threshold for independent retirees. We have put in place a number of strategies already to improve our support for older Australians, but we need to also put in place longer term planning policies that will encourage self-sufficiency and greater saving for retirement, that will remove the incentives for earlier retirement and that will provide job opportunities for mature age employees.

The average age of retirement in Australia is 58, which is too low. We need to encourage people to stay in the workplace longer. Firstly, this will reduce the pressures on taxation revenue and will reduce the rise in the dependency ratio. Secondly, it will reduce the level of dissaving and the double-dipping that occurs. Thirdly, it will delay the threshold of pension dependency along with a level of pension dependency. We need to encourage people to stay in the workplace longer, and this is one of the principles that the OECD enunciated in its approach to adequately providing long-term planning for retirement.

This government is introducing necessary reforms to plan for this issue and to plan for an ageing demographic. We have already introduced a pension bonus plan for delayed retirement. We have introduced a graded raising of the superannuation preservation age for those born after 1964. We have introduced moves to end the compulsory retirement age of 65 in the Commonwealth Public Service. We have introduced a graded rise in the pensionable age for women to eventually bring it up to the same level as it is for men. We need to introduce improvements also in incentives for people to continue in part-time or temporary work so that they can increase their level of independence and reduce the call on savings and, ultimately, the age pension.

There is still much more that needs to be done. Attention needs to be given to the interface between incomes, pensions and tax rates. We have started to make progress in this area. The reduction in the income-pension trade-off from 50 cents in the dollar to 40 cents in the dollar under the new tax package to be introduced next year is a big improvement to provide incentive for older Australians. The lower income tax rate and the higher tax-free threshold under the ANTS package will also be a big improvement. Capital gains tax rollover relief for small business, the removal of provisional tax and the refund of excess dividend imputation credits are all improvements which will help. There is a need for greater flexibility for people to move in and out of temporary work, contract work and casual work, particularly in those immediate pre-pension years and in the post-pension years. There needs to be greater incentive to invest for retirement, and this government's proposals for capital gains tax will certainly help in that regard. We need to introduce policies to make it easier for mature age unemployedâthose involuntarily unemployedâto re-enter the work force, otherwise we lose an extremely valuable resource in knowledge and skills. We need to introduce greater incentive job training policies to overcome discrimination and prejudice in the work force, we need to consider incentives for employers to take on mature age unemployed and we need to remove some of the structural obstacles to employing older people. For instance, in no state except Queensland and the ACT is there workers compensation past the age of 65. We need to remove these restrictions that make it harder for employers to take on mature age unemployed people.

The second challenge for us is to provide appropriate health care levels for an ageing community. Clearly, an ageing population will bring with it growing expenditure on health care. The demand for health care for people over 65 is 3.8 times higher than it is for people under 65, rising to five times as much for people over 75. This includes acute health care, pharmaceuticals and the need for residential health care. The OECD estimates that, for Australia, government health outlays will rise by about 2Â½ per cent of GDP over the next 30 years. This government has increased already the allocation of funding for aged care from $2.3 billion per annum in 1996 to $2.9 billion this year. But there is a long way to go. We are already putting in place other improvements to help take the pressure off residential aged care: the $270 million Staying at Home package to remove the pressure to move into residential care; the introduction of a lifetime community rating for private health insurance; the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate; the extension of the seniors health care card to another 220,000 people; improved domiciliary nursing care benefits; the extension of the veterans gold card, et cetera.

There is a need for much more long-term planning in this area. In my own electorate in the Blue Mountains and the Hawkesbury we have considerable areas of need for aged care. Certainly we are seeing improvements. We saw last year the opening of a new hostel, Morven Gardens, with 60 beds. We have seen planning for a new nursing home attached to Hawkesbury Village with 61 beds. We are seeing an increase in day respite facilities with the recent awarding of $250,000 per annum to Anglicare to provide for day respite for people with dementia. But there is still a need for increased funding for more aged care places and more community aged care packages for the Blue Mountains and for the Hawkesbury to allow for the ageing demographic in my electorate. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd: Steelworks

talk.start.para: âNearly a fortnight ago BHP announced the result of its steel portfolio review. BHP intends to become a major, world-class natural resource company with a strategic interest in steel making. BHP, in its press release of 6 October 1999, stated it will become:

speech.para: . . . a simpler business, focusing on those areas in which BHP has ongoing operational and marketing advantages, which are consistent with its strategic objectives, and which generate substantial shareholder value.

Following the announcement, BHP will concentrate on flat products in Australia, New Zealand and Asia and service the building and construction markets internationally. The announcement has major implications for BHP steel operations based in the heart of my electorate. The Port Kembla steelworks will become the jewel in the crown of BHP's steel operation in Australia.

When the announcement was made nearly a fortnight ago, I broadly welcomed its measures in my public statements. I am obviously very pleased that the Port Kembla operation, which is the most cost-effective holding for BHP in its steel portfolio with its low cost supply of steel and leading position in coated steel, will become a key asset for steel production in this country. Illawarra steel workers and the major steel unions can feel more secure about BHP's future operations at Port Kembla. I note that the public statements of steel union officials, particularly from the Port Kembla Branch of the Australian Workers Union, have been broadly positive since the announcement was made. I also understand that meetings of steel union delegates have taken place over the last week, giving union officials the opportunity to explain the BHP restructure to its workers.

I think it is important to place on the record that the work done by steel workers and the steel unions in my region, over the last two decades especially, has contributed crucially to the positive performance of steel production in my region. The huge capital investment injection which has been pumped into the Port Kembla steel operation over the last few years has been nothing short of a vote of confidence in the steel work force in the Illawarra. There was a time when my region copped a hiding from critical media coverage about industrial relations strife and poor productivity, much of it, in my view, unfair and a diversion from the inability of managers to deal with their workers and the Illawarra unions. All of this crucial attention was focused on three main industries in my regionâsteel was one, coal was the other and the waterfront was the last. Over the last two decades, and published in a series of reports on regional development and industrial relations, the critical perception of the Illawarra as an industrial relations wasteland has been properly shelved once and for all.

I am concerned that BHP intends to divest itself of its Tin Mill Products holding. In the Illawarra about 1,500 workers will be affected by this decision. On the day that this part of the announcement was made, I raised my concerns directly in correspondence with the President, BHP Flat Products, Mr George Edgar. The following day he did me the courtesy of a reply. It appears we are all joined in our concern to ensure that the Tin Mill Products employees in my region are looked after when a new owner can be found for the operation. I want any new owner or joint venturer for the Tin Mill Products division to ensure the retention of each of those jobs. Tin Mill Product's existing plant has very good equipment and, as George Edgar said to me in his reply to my letter, `good people', and that should ring in the ears of any potential new owner of the mill.

Despite the positive features of this announcement for the Illawarra region, there are continuing worrying indications that there is a strategic withdrawal from steel making taking place in Australia. I have been concerned for a number of years that there is a view developing in Australia that it should quit steel production.

In 1997 I served on the all-party committee that assessed the Australian iron and steel industry and reported to the then Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. This committee was established following the BHP announcement that it would close the Newcastle steelworks after 87 years of steel production. The committee travelled around Australia. It visited steel operations throughout the country, met with steel industry representatives, trade unions and community organisations, and presented its report in September 1997. From memory, I do not believe that the Howard government ever responded to any of the recommendations in that report. No doubt it occupies a nice place on some departmental shelf, attracting its appropriate hold of dust. If Australia quits the steel making industry, frankly, it forfeits its manufacturing industry.

On two occasions in the last two years, Australia's primary producer of steel has made significant announcements, and the Howard government has said nothing. The then minister, I recall, went off to play blackjack and the current minister issued a media release saying only that the government will not interfere in what is essentially a commercial decision.

The Hawke Labor government in 1983, faced with a similar crisis in steel making, intervened to save an industry that employed hundreds of thousands of workers and earned Australia billions of dollars in export income. In the first 100 days of the Hawke government, steel making in Australia was rescued by the implementation of a five-year steel plan. The Hawke government came out with a carrot and a stick, directed at both the company and the unions. What was achieved by this intervention? BHP committed to investing nearly $1 billion in its steel plants, the government would provide nearly $100 million a year in bounty payments and the unions would exercise wage restraint and productivity targets.

The results were a viable Australian steel industry. Profitability was restored, productivity was lifted by at least 40 per cent, industrial disputation was slashed and steel export rose dramatically. BHP ended up investing $2 billion into steel upgrades during the life of the steel plant, and in the following decade invested up to $7 billionâalthough some of this dramatic investment went into holdings that have cost BHP dearly over recent times and is one of the reasons for their announcement in the last fortnight. The Howard government's response has once again shown that it has no industry policy and no regional development policy. It has no plans, no ideas and no vision, and it is content to leave everything to the market.

I took great interest in an article in the business section of the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday headed `Now, at your service', which covered the BHP announcement. Throughout the article there appeared to be pride in the fact that:

. . . as BHP retreated from its once seemingly impregnable bastion of steel, there were no industry plans and no offers of assistance from Federal or State Governments to hold back the inevitability of change.

The article mentioned that in the United States the so-called rust beltâwhich has had a decline in traditional industries such as steel, car manufacturing and other heavy industryâis being replaced by `vibrant centres of growth and job creation'. This is trueâand some of this kind of transformation in industry can be seen in regions such as the Illawarra, which is a leader in the telecommunications industryâbut it should be highlighted that many of these new industries in the United States operate in foreign trade zones. In other words, they are provided with assistance by state and federal governments. This, incidentally, was recommendation No. 6 in the minority report of Labor MPs on the all party committee assessing the steel industry, which I mentioned earlier.

The BHP announcement on 6 October has positive features for my electorate and my region, which I have publicly and broadly welcomed. But I do not kid myself into believing that this is the end of such announcements. Unless there is a substantial shift in the policy thinking in government, bureaucracy and business away from blind faith in the market, a big announcement will one day be made. I can see the day, perhaps in the next five years or so, when an announcement will be made that Australia no longer is to be involved in steel making. The question will then be: do we greet this announcement with a shrug of the shoulders, or do we kick ourselves about yet another lost opportunity and yet another lost industry? I have said it many times: it is essential that Australia maintains its position as a world producer of steel. We have the equipment, the workers and the infrastructure at Port Kembla to make sure that Australia takes its place as a leading producer of steel.

talk.start.para: âOver the weekend in Townsville in the suburb of Currajong someone set fire to an Australian flag hung out on display at the residence of Barbara and Noel Lucas. Mr and Mrs Lucas had put the flag up as a symbolic and public show of support for their son serving in East Timor, Corporal Keith Lucas. The flag had been raised for display on the day that Corporal Lucas and many other Townsville based men and women of our ADF were deployed to East Timor as part of the INTERFET force. According to reports in today's Townsville Bulletin , the flag was set alight some time in the early hours of Sunday morning. If this was simply an act of petty vandalism, all I can say is that I hope the person or persons responsible are ashamed of their actions and of the hurt and concern that they have caused to the Lucas family and other defence families in Townsville. The decent thing to do would be to own up and apologise in person to Mr and Mrs Lucas and to their family.

speech.para: If, however, this is a more sinister political attack on Australia's military role in East Timor, then I call on local residents to support the Lucas family and all of our defence personnel in East Timor by flying Australian flags in a similar public fashion. Residents in Townsville and Thuringowa have responded magnificently to our efforts in East Timor and to the needs and concerns of local defence families. After all, more than 2,000 of the troops from Townsville are currently in East Timor. Townsville's bus and taxi drivers, for example, are to be commended for wearing their hearts and national pride on their sleeves by flying small Australian flags on their radio aerials and on vehicles in support of our troops in East Timor. I call on residents to follow their lead and to fly a flag for freedom in East Timor; fly a flag in support of our Defence Force personnel and their families.

Another matter I want to raise today concerns the serious mineral exploration industry downturn that has occurred in Queensland and probably throughout Australia. Mineral exploration and mining companies are very concerned about the current state of their industryâ
Mr Melham interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou ought to listen to this, the member for Banks. They have linked many of their concerns back to the vexed question of native title in Australia and to the native title legislation being put forward by the Queensland state government in particular. Their core concerns are tied up with the section of the Beattie government's native title act relating to access to the exploration permit tenements to undertake drilling operations. They know that, by dividing exploration tenements into `low impact' and `high impact' categories, new exploration work simply will not proceed and is not proceeding. Under the state government's legislation, low impact exploration activity is characterised as a drilling activity that, firstly, does not include clearing or site excavation, other than the minimum necessary to establish a drill pad for a mobile rig and, secondly, does not include clearing of a road or trackâamongst other characteristics and requirements.

speech.para: There is almost never a road to the site where a geo wants to drill an exploration hole. The industry's point is that this effectively will mean that it must apply for a high impact exploration permit. This then means that the organisation must enter into protracted negotiations and compensation agreements, including payments, with native title holders. I heard today the ultimate irony, that indigenous people in the Torres Strait are frustrated that they cannot get on with some exploration activity because of this particular situation. In a letter to the Queensland Premier in August, one exploration company said:

By making exploration difficult and more complicated the government has simply provided a strong disincentive for major mining and junior explorers to participate in the industry throughout Queensland.

The message is blunt and practical: if you do not drill for new mineral deposits, you do not make new discoveries. If you do not make new discoveries, your resources eventually dry up. If your resources dry up, regional centres like Townsville will bear the economic and employment consequences.

While Townsville itself is not a mining town, it is very much a base for mineral refining, mineral export and mineral exploration operations. In 1994, 1995 and 1996, there were 13 mineral exploration companies operating out of Townsville. Since 1996, the number of exploration offices has fallen to five. Companies such as CRA, Goldfields, Western Mining Corporation, Barkely Minerals, Dominion and Aberfoyle have all closed their office doors in Townsville in this period of time. These offices directly employed about 79 geologists and support staff.

Let us look at Mount Isa, previously one of Australia's main exploration bases for all the major mining companies, including CRA and BHP. Mount Isa is now an exploration ghetto, a ghost town as far as exploration is concerned. All the majors have packed up and gone. It is now likely that the three major supply companies will also close. So why have exploration units closed down in the north-west minerals province, the largest minerals province in the world? The answer lies in native title. Exploration companies simply cannot get new tenements to explore, so their view is, `What's the point in hanging around? We may as well go away.'

The state government hears but it says and does nothing. While low commodity prices have been a factor, I believe that the native title issue is the major factor contributing to the uncertainty that has been crippling the exploration industry. Seventy per cent of trained geologists currently in Australia are out of work. Clearly, this is not good news for the minerals exploration industry in general or the local Townsville and Thuringowa community in particular.

The concerns being expressed by those in the industry who speak out are not isolated comments, either. They represent the serious concerns of the mining and exploration industry in general. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures released last month show private spending on minerals exploration has fallen to its lowest level in five years. In response to the figures, the Minerals Council of Australia said the depressed state of this vital job generating industry was due to a range of factors, including native title. Last month, the Australian Drilling Industry Association echoed these sentiments, saying that there were many factors affecting their industryâsuch as commodity prices, the Asian crisis and the value of the Australian dollarâbut that the underlying problem was that of native title.

The association's executive officer, Graeme Wakeling, described his members as being in dire trouble, with more than $100 million worth of exploration equipment in Queensland sitting idle because of native title constraints. In an article last month in the Courier-Mail, Mr Wakeling said:
Some companies are still carrying out some limited exploration work. However, this is generally restricted to land that is not affected by native title.

Everyone's concern is that problems and confusion associated with native title are not just driving minerals exploration companies out of regional centres like Townsville but are forcing Australian companies overseas.

As stated by one CEO of an exploration company in an article in the Financial Review on 6 October of this year, `It is easier to explore in Iran than it is in Queensland.' What a disgraceful state of affairs! This too is not an isolated comment and was a point noted earlier this year by the chief economist of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, who said that over half the mining companies that he had spoken to had expressed concern about exploration levels in Australia. In an article in the Financial Review in June, Mr Rob Henderson said that miners:
are looking offshore in places like Africa, Asia and South America. That's a potential negative, not necessarily for the companies, but for Australian exports.

The Financial Review article went on to say that native title issues were harming the industry's longer term decisions, though some companies were bypassing government to negotiate directly with Aboriginal Australians.

As honourable members will know, the mining industry has for years operated in a cyclic phase. It goes into an upturn and then back into a downturn, and so on. The industry worldwide is just coming off the bottom of the last downturn. Higher commodity prices are certainly driving the latest upturn. This is the time when mining houses need confidence to increase their spending on exploration. Sadly, this looks very unlikely. The consequence of the native title problem, which is uncertainty, is going to make Australia miss out on the next boom.

talk.start.para: âIn this grievance speech I would like to refer to the rapid social, industrial and economic change taking place in Western Sydney and in my electorate of Greenway in particular. I will refer to the sadness, hope and opportunity that the change will bring about.

speech.para: As a reflection of the district's rural past we have three Country Women's Association branches functioning in the electorate: at Blacktown, Quakers Hill and Riverstone. These three organisations continue to contribute to the district socially by charity fund raising as well as being a link with the younger generation. I particularly enjoy attending the international day at the Quakers Hill Country Women's Association where schoolchildren from the local primary school, Quakers Hill East, present a display of a particular country which has been chosen to be studied for that year.

Unfortunately, Quakers Hill Country Women's Association is moving through a sad period as they prepare to move out of the hall they have occupied for almost half a century. This hall was bought from Schofields in 1955 and it has been the home of this organisation since then. Fortunately, the association will continue to hold their meetings in the Quakers Hill Community Centre. I wish Mrs Paynter, the association president, and her members, all the best in their new accommodation.

The electorate is seeing many new extremely large residential developments being undertaken, one of these being at Stanhope Gardens, which will become the model for future housing developments in Western Sydney. A special feature of this development is a $400 million Landcom project which will include crime minimisation designs such as no rear lanes and no back fencing facing into reserves and parks. Every house should be within 400 metres of a bus stop or cycling and road share way used by both pedestrians and motorists. These features were requested by the local council based on its past experience with other residential developments in the Blacktown local government area. The new 189-hectare suburb will have about 2,000 homes, four schools, a retail town centre and community facilities. The Stanhope Gardens Residents Association president, Dushan Djukic, is particularly impressed with the way the developer, Landcom, has maintained links to the physical surroundings and the historical nature of the site.

I have presented to the House these two brief examples of the changes taking place in Western Sydney that go towards making up the thriving city of Blacktown. This city has recently held a local government election which resulted in the election of some new councillors and the departure of some previous councillors within my electorate of Greenway. I present the names of these peopleâboth past and presentâin recognition of the contribution that each has made to the growth of our city. Those departing were Michael Somerton, Michael Corbin and Geoff Bisby. Elected were: Alan Pendletonâthe new mayorâRon Alder, David Poole, Leo Kellyânow deputy mayorâCon Constantine, Len Robinson, Barbara Gapps, Kathie Collins and Russ Dickens. I mention these names, irrespective of the political parties the people belong to, as a recognition of the great work that the Blacktown council in general is doing for the citizens of that city.

Blacktown city has a population of over 240,000 and covers an area of 241 square kilometres. Blacktown city is strategically located just 35 kilometres west of Sydney CBD and is one of Australia's fastest growing urban areas. The city itself is located in the heartland of Greater Western Sydney and is now a prosperous urban community with a thriving industrial and commercial base.

This great city is home to a wide range of readily available industrial and commercial land and an extensive network of major transport links which will provide a direct access to local, national and international markets with the completion of the Western Sydney orbital road link. Of great interest is the revelation that the city is home to a number of Australia's major tourism and recreational attractions. Tourism is an important part of Blacktown's economy. The most recent estimate by Tourism New South Wales shows that, of Sydney's LGAs, Blacktown is ranked third by both number of nights spent by visitors in the area and expenditure raised. The major tourist attractions in the city region are Featherdale Wildlife Park, Sydney's Wonderland and the Eastern Creek Raceway for motor vehicle competitions. There are also many passive recreational facilities in the city area, such as the enormously popular Prospect Reservoir and the Nurragingy Reserve, which provide a venue for so many happy family gatherings throughout the whole year for an area that is so far away from the east coast beaches of New South Wales.

The local labour market remains strong. Over the past two years there has been an increase in the labour force participation rate, which remains significantly higher than for the rest of the Sydney metropolitan area. The number of job advertisements in Blacktown LGA has grown significantly. From October 1998 to February 1999 there was an overall increase of 12 per cent. Over the past year there has been a 36 per cent increase in advertisementsâmore than double the rise in either New South Wales or across Australia.

However, I move to my strong grievance about the infrastructure development that is being held up in Western Sydney by the failure of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services to provide funds for the completion of the Western Sydney Orbital Road System. With Sydney's population expected to increase to almost 4.5 million within the next two decades, it is anticipated that half of Sydney's future housing needs will be met in newly developed areas that are available in Western Sydney. As I have said so many times in this House, to meet existing and future demands, the construction of the Western Sydney Orbital Road System is now extremely urgent. The existing road network out from Sydney's CBD is radial and lacks cross-regional links between employment zones and regional centres.

I have constantly brought to the attention of the minister the problems of the high levels of congestion being increasingly experienced on existing road networks. Roads such as the M4, M5 and Cumberland Highway are Western Sydney's major freight corridors. The capacity of the M4 has already been reached with 4,200 vehicles at peak-hour traffic times. I have consistently raised the issueâas have many local organisationsâthat this congestion is threatening the competitiveness of industry and commerce located in Greater Western Sydney, due to insufficient freight movements and longer transport times.

It seems so patently clear to all of us with a knowledge of Western Sydney that the construction of the Western Sydney orbital would overcome these problems by improving access to employment, education, cultural and retail facilities in Western Sydney by reducing travelling time and transport costs. Local communities would be overjoyed by a major side effect in that the Western Sydney orbital would also redirect regional traffic away from residential centres, thus reducing local traffic congestion, noise and pollution. Our local communities would also welcome the fact that interregional traffic would be removed from roads fronted by homes, schools child-care centres, nursing homes and hospitals.

The New South Wales RTA has estimated that there would be a considerable reduction in regional road traffic, ranging from 10 per cent to 45 per cent, with the construction of the Western Sydney orbital. By the year 2019, Western Sydney will have a population greater than the rest of Sydney. It is time for the minister to act and to act quickly to provide these much needed funds which will enable the orbital to be completed and which will provide such a huge boost to the local residential communities and to the economies of the business communities as well. I grieve that on the horizon there appears, at this stage, to be little likelihood of action from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, and I believe this remains a blot on the record of this minister and his predecessor. I thank members of the House for their courtesy.

subdebateinfo.title: East Timor
Australian Ex-Prisoners of War Memorial Appeal
Ballarat Electorate: Online Australia Field Day

talk.start.para: âI have great pleasure in speaking on the grievance debate tonight. All Australians can be proud, in my view, of the leadership role Australia is playing in East Timor. I think it is fair to say that all Australians cannot be as proud of events over the last 24 years. I thought it was interesting the other day when the Parliamentarians for East Timor group met with Xanana Gusmao, that Mr Gusmao told the Parliamentarians for East Timor that his people were looking forwardânot looking backâto a constructive relationship with Indonesia. I and other members of the group were impressed with the commitment of Xanana Gusmao on behalf of his peopleâto look forward rather than back.

speech.para: It is probably not widely known that Australia has given some $50 million in aid to East Timor since 1980, under a variety of political parties. That is more than any other donor country has given. The member for Moncrieff quite rightly made that point a couple of weeks ago in the House. That aid was, of course, desperately needed. East Timor is stricken by severe povertyâa poverty that has, I think, shocked the Western world in the last month. Eighty per cent of East Timor's population depend on subsistence agriculture for their livelihood. In 1990, life expectancy was found to be at a low 57 years, with infant mortality at an appalling 124 in every 1,000 live births. I think that would horrify honourable members, as it horrified me when I heard the honourable member for Moncrieff quote those figures. A 1992 UNICEF study found that more than half of East Timorese children under five were malnourished. Australia's response to the situation has been comprehensive. Our response to the horrible violence that followed the independence vote on 30 August has also been comprehensive.

Today is the 29th day that the INTERFET forces have been on the ground in East Timor. They have been protecting the East Timorese people, they have been disarming the militia and restoring order to a place where chaos reigned only six weeks ago. In the circumstances, the response of the Australian government, I believe, has been outstanding. But we will have to be there for the long haul. I think we are all waiting and hoping that the Blue Helmets will be in East Timor sooner rather than later. Obviously, there is a lot more that needs to happen before that eventuates but, once we see the blue helmets there, we will know that the work of INTERFET has been done and that phase 3 of the East Timorese move towards independence will be on its way to having succeeded.

On Saturday, as a member of the Parliamentarians for East Timor, I attended a seminar organised in Ballarat titled `What can we do for East Timor?' When the East Timor crisis first started in its present form a coalition of interested members in the Ballarat community was formed. A variety of peopleâincluding me, both the Catholic and Anglican bishops and a large number of other peopleâwere involved in that coalition. I would like to pay tribute here to Mr David MacPhail. David was the one who originally got people organised for this meeting and we met at my office. The coalition has now disbanded because the Australia East Timor Association, Ballarat Branch, was officially launched on Saturday. I am sure Brian Martin, who operates from the Trades Hall, will do a terrific job. I had my photo taken with Mr Martin, and there was some suggestion that it should hang in the Ballarat Trades Hall, but I have said that I think in all the circumstances it should perhaps hang in the main street rather than in the Trades Hall.

Another issue in relation to East Timor which is of importance is the AusAID and Austrade joint seminar being held here in Canberra tomorrow to brief Australian companies wishing to assist in the rebuilding of East Timor. Not only companies in Canberra but companies right throughout Australia can play their part in addressing what will be a massive reconstruction of East Timor. There is an enormous amount of work to do, as honourable members will know.

I was very pleased a couple of weeks ago to talk about members of the armed forces who come from my own area of Ballarat. I would like to pay tribute to Mrs Jenny Ashley of Mount Clear who has started a support group for the local families of those serving in the INTERFET force. As I said to the support group for family members at the Ballarat RSLâorganised by Phil Horwood, with the local president thereâthey are, in some respects, suffering as much as their family members in East Timor. At least the person serving knows what is happening, because he or she is on the ground over there, but for the families here it is very difficult to know what is happeningâfor security reasons, obviously. They have to wait for that bit of news that comes through, mainly via the Australian media.

While we are acknowledging bravery in wartime in a permanent way, I want to talk again about the Australian Ex-Prisoners of War Memorial Appeal. The memorial is to be based in Ballarat. It has been actively supported by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Bruce Scott. The Australian government has donated $50,000 towards that memorial, as well as giving tax deductibility status, which is obviously essential for this very ambitious $1.5 to $2 million program. This national appeal is raising money to build a memorial to all Australian ex-POWs from the Boer War, the First World War, the Second World War and the Korean War.

Nearly 35,000 names will be engraved into the granite wall, which will include a separate section for the 8,684 Australians who died in captivity mainly due to brutality, starvation and disease. This memorial was designed by Ballarat artist, Peter Blizzard, and will be built in the Botanical Gardens. Significantly, it is the only memorial in Australia which recognises all POWs from those theatres of war that I mentioned before.

Befitting a national launch, the ceremony to launch the appeal was attended by the official Prisoner of War Association representatives from Queensland, Melbourne, Sydney and Adelaide; RSL National President Major General Phillips AO MC, retired; local ex-POWs; returned service men and women; state parliamentarians and civic leaders. It was a special day and a milestone for those who put countless hours into the project since it was first unofficially launched in 1996.

I would like to congratulate Mr David Baird OAM, who recently stepped down as committee chair, and the project coordinator, Mr Les Kennedy, for the work they have done. They led an extremely hardworking and diligent committee. The fruits of their labour are now being born, which they deserve. Their great concern was the age of many POWs now. They wanted to make sure that those men and women were alive to see this national memorial being erected on their behalf.

I notice that we are broadcasting at the moment. I know a lot of people listen to parliament. Can I plead with those who are listening and to honourable members on both sides of the House to assist in this fundraising event. It cannot be done by the community of Ballarat alone. It is a national memorial celebrating and commemorating those 35,000-odd people I referred to before, our fellow Australians who were POWs.

If anyone listening would like to donate to this cause, they can contact my office in Ballarat or in Canberra. I would urge all Australians to make this a national fundraising appeal. Of all people, prisoners of war are those who light a fire in the belly of all Australians. We should especially remember those 8,500 of our fellow Australians who died in captivity in the most appalling conditions that we cannot even imagine. As I said before, I urge all Australians to support this national memorial to the POWs.

There is a forthcoming event in my electorate as well which I want to bring to the attention of honourable members tonightâthat is, the Online Australia Field Day, which will be held on 19 and 20 November. It has been organised by the Centre for Electronic Commerce and Communications at the University of Ballarat. The field day has been modelled on the successful agricultural field day concept and will have a rural focus. Attractions include field demonstrations showing the use of online technology in rural operations, a business expo and activities for children, including a kids tentâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis evening I grieve that inequality in our society is increasing rather than decreasing. Recently, it was reported that some 18 per cent of Australians under the age of 15 were growing up in households where no parent had a job. This compares to something like 1.7 million children under 15âthat is, 42.5 per cent of Australia's youngâwho are living in the relative security of a two-income family. Also it has been recently reported that the income share gap between rich and poor has continued to expand rather than contract.

speech.para: Figures from the Bureau of Statistics indicated that, in 1997-98, the income share of the bottom 20 per cent was just 8.3 per cent, down from 9.8 per cent a year earlier. At the same time, the top 20 per cent had increased their share from 38.4 per cent to 41.2 per cent. While the average weekly income of the bottom 20 per cent increased by just $7 over the three years to 1997-98, their counterparts in the top 20 per cent saw their average weekly income increase by a massive $121 per week.

Wage disparity continues to be a major problem for our society. This inequality is exacerbated when the salaries of elite groups seem to increase without justification. The salaries of executives seem to obscenely skyrocket regularly as ordinary workers are lectured continually by economists and government ministers about the morals of wage restraint. Executives at the top 50 companies gained, on average, $155,000 in the last year. Their median pay went from $1 million to $1.155 million. This represents a massive increase of 15 per cent, compared to ordinary workers who saw their pay increase by a mere three per cent over the same period. This is not about the politics of envy; this is something that should be of grave concern to all. These enormous salaries do not reflect the performance of the executives, and there never appears to be any relationship between the remuneration and the level of performance demanded in return.

The case of Tabcorp's chief executive, Ross Wilson, is one that I have drawn to the House's attention before. Mr Wilson was paid $675,000 initially in 1993-94, with an interest free loan of $6.75 million to buy shares in Tabcorp. By 1997, his salary had increased to $1 million and his shares had appreciated by some $10 million. This was despite the debacle of Melbourne Cup Day 1996 when computer malfunctions at Tabcorp meant that many ordinary Victorians were deprived of the opportunity to place a bet on the most important racing day in the country. This proves, yet again, that executive salaries, unlike most everyone else's in the community, do not appear to be linked to performance or productivity.

On Friday, 1 October, yet again, due to a computer malfunction at Tabcorp, Tabcorp customers were unable to get their winning bets funded. In fact, they were not able to find out how much they had actually won. There continued to be ads over the next 10 days asking these customers of Tabcorp to bear with the organisation because of the problems they were having with their computer system. This happened on a Friday when there were four race meetings. If it had happened on a Saturday, when there are interstate race meetings, it would have been much worse.

I was quite surprised, therefore, to see it reported in the Financial Review last week that Mr Wilson's salary has increased to $1.56 million and his Tabcorp shares are now worth $40.7 million. In addition, he has agreed to stay on until 2002 and will receive options on over three million Tabcorp shares for doing so. This was reported last week, at the same time as Tabcorp telephone betting operators rejected the 8.5 per cent offered to them as inadequate and threatened industrial action. They based their claim on the fact that telephone betting had increased by 22.7 per cent over 12 months and that they wanted a fair share, seeing as their chief executive officer was sitting on an overall package of some $44.5 million.

It is not just wage disparity which is contributing to the increase in inequality in our society. There was an allegation made that Labor governments presided over a decrease in the value of real wages. Yet Labor governments attempted to remedy this through the social wage. Through initiatives such as the introduction and expansion of Medicare and the revolution in access to higher education that occurred under Labor governments, government services were delivered to those in our community who had never been able to afford them.

Last week the Howard government's secret plans for higher education were revealed. These plans would strip away the gains made in the social wage for those on lower incomes in our community, denying them in many cases access to higher education. These plans come at a time when our public hospital infrastructures in many states are an absolute disgrace after years of shameful neglect and resource starving by conservative state administrations. Given events in my state of Victoria this morning, thankfully there will be one less conservative government after tomorrow.

If we have a look at the way the public health system works in the state of Victoria, if one needs to be admitted as an in-patient from a casualty centre in a public hospital, one might stay for two or three nights on a trolley in casualty. If one has private cover, one can immediately find a bed in a private hospital. If a public patient has to have a test like an angiogram or a gastroscopy, they will wait weeks to get that test done. If they are a private patient, they will get it immediately. This is a further indication of the growing disparity within our society.

I am concerned that, given the increasing reliance on information technology, lower income people will also end up becoming the information poor if access to this technology is not improved. The inequality is not just manifesting itself through lopsided wage outcomes and access to services. It is actively being encouraged by government policy. I mentioned the secret plans for education revealed last week as an example of the widening inequality. It is sadly not the only example coming from this government. The government has announced a major shake-up in the wake of the Ralph Review of Business Taxation. There is of course in itself nothing wrong with reforming the business tax system. Over its 13 years in office, Labor was constantly reforming the entire tax system, with measures such as the introduction of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the lowering of business tax rates and personal tax rates.

The aims of any proposals for business taxation reform should be to improve the competitiveness of Australian industry and to use the tax system to help create more jobs and investment. Of course, the test of the proposals is to do this while ensuring that business carries its fair share of the tax burden. It is here that the government's response to the Ralph recommendations fails.

The government's proposals leave a massive $3.8 billion hole in revenue. They fail the government's own test, which was that the overall package was to be revenue neutral. This $3.8 billion hole is unacceptable at a time when Australians are about to be slugged with a 10 per cent tax on nearly everything they do or buy. It is a sign of increasing inequality in our society that the consumer in the supermarket ends up paying so that business is let off the hook of its fair share of taxâbecause at the end of the day, that is what is going to happen. Whether it be through the GST or cuts to Commonwealth outlays in areas like health and education, the ordinary taxpayer will end up paying to plug this gap.

The shifting of the burden on to those who can least afford it has been a worrying worldwide development over the last few decades. In his book The good society: the humane agenda, J.K. Galbraith states:

. . . the most effective instrument for achieving a greater measure of income equality remains the progressive income tax. This has the central role in accomplishing a reasonable, even civilised distribution of income. Nothing else, it may be added, is subject to such highly motivated and wholly predictable attack.

With this government's shift to increasing reliance on consumption tax and now this business tax reform, there is a very real attack on the progressive income taxation system designed to shift an increasing amount of the tax burden on to PAYE taxpayersâin other words, to those who truly can least afford it.

Australians constantly pride themselves on the egalitarian nature of the society we have created for ourselves. However, that egalitarianism and sense of fair go that many Australians display in their dealings with each other on a personal level is increasingly becoming something that is not borne out by the statistics. If inequality is allowed to continue unchecked, permanent underclasses entrench themselves and the related problems become so much harder to deal with. If inequality is actively encouraged by government policy, that entrenchment occurs all the more quickly. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTonight in this grievance debate I would like to talk about health funding. It is a bit of a mantra of mine and I will never resile from it. It is an issue that causes a great deal of friction between the Commonwealth and the states. A number of state premiers and health ministers, particularly in Queensland, have criticised the federal government for not providing enough funding, and recently there have been renewed calls for an inquiry into health in Australia.

speech.para: The problems of Queensland health will not be solved by a Senate inquiry or a wider inquiry; an inquiry would only confirm that the federal government is providing record levels of health funding to the states. Public hospital funding will increase by $7.2 billion in the next five years, an increase of more than 30 per cent. My premise is that there is no necessity for an inquiry into health funding in Australia, but there could well be an inquiry into health funding in some of the statesâand I do not exempt Queensland from that. The Commonwealth has delivered an extra 19.2 per cent to the states, which blunts the argument that we are cutting back funding in the public sector. The problems in Queensland lie with Labor's philosophy and its own administration of health.

As honourable members know, I do not try to be particularly political in these matters, but I have made a bit of a study of this matter. The problems began in Queensland in the early 1990s under the Goss government. But the trouble really set in when they got to their second three-year term. Working off a benchmark of $685 million in the year 1991-92, their funding for the next three years was $661 million, $569 million and $656 million respectively. You might ask: what does that mean? Let me contrast that with the federal funding for Queensland. Working off a benchmark of a similar figure of $669 million, we find that for the next three years the federal funding was $699 million, $776 million and $812 million respectively. In other words, as the federal government put money into the system, the state was either not topping it up or in a way just taking it out. That changed when the Borbidge government came to power in 1996 and 1997âstate funding increased significantly and matched federal funding.

The problem of ineffective use of federal funds is beginning to surface again under the current Labor government in Queensland. In my electorate of Hinkler, the Bundaberg Base Hospital has suffered this year due to underfunding and bureaucratic bungles. The hospital was coming in $1.1 million short on its budget. It was accused of overspending and was told that it would have to operate within its budget. When it became obvious that it could not, the state government made a loan available. But what it did not say was that of the $1.1 million provided $200,000 was transferred from the mental health budget and $700,000 was sidelined for elective surgery and had to be returned to Brisbane unspent at the end of the financial year. So, in effect, the hospital received in net terms $100,000.

Despite the protestations of the minister for health and authorities at the time that the hospital had to live within its budget, within six months the state government had to concede this fiasco of special funding and, in its more recent budget, increased the funding for the Bundaberg Base Hospital by $2 millionâ$1.2 million was added to the operating budget, which only goes to prove what the hospital administration had been saying for the previous two years, that the hospital was underfunded by around $1 million to $1.5 million. In fact, the state government only confirmed what everyone knew. But worse than thatâworse in one sense and good in anotherâthe state government provided another $800,000 for growth funding. That is very interesting: the state government said that the hospital would have to live within its budget but then suddenly granted $800,000 to the hospital. The state government defeated its own purpose because it admitted not only that the operational budget was underfunded but also that the hospital was in need of growth funding. I will be watching very closely and with interest how that money is administered.

It seems that the state Labor government in Queensland has a fetish about tiers of bureaucracy. During the previous Goss administration, regional health authorities were set up. These were wasteful authorities. They employed some 300 people. Their cost estimates ranged as high as $15 million and all they did was take people from the bedside. When these authorities were dismantled very little could be seen on the surface for their having been there over the previous years. But having got rid of them and returned to regional health councils, which were a form of the old hospital boards, unfortunately without statutory authority, the state government is now going to put in three new positions worth $180,000 a year. As the state shadow health minister Fiona Simpson states, these three new zone manager positions will invalidate the role of the district health managers and the district health councils which have only just been established. To some extent, it will impinge on their authority and some think this will make them toothless tigers.

This is certainly an innovative approach, having these managers who are going to oversee regional areas but who will live in Brisbane and be attached to hospitals. These new positions not only take power away from regional and rural communities of Queensland and their hospitals' administration but also are not even in the country. That could be a blessing in disguise, I suppose, insofar as we will not get another repetition I hope of these needless bureaucracies, but it is a very inter esting trendâgoing back to another layer of bureaucracy, not away from it. I propose that we do something quite different: we should enhance the role of the regional health councils and return them to boards with statutory authority.

The other thing that troubles me in this matter of health is the lack of doctors in rural and regional areas. This is not something that has happened overnight; this has been a creeping disease, so to speak, for many years. The current government is doing what it can to address that problem. We have put a number of initiatives in place such as two rural medical campusesâone at Wagga and one at Townsvilleâthe John Flynn scholarships for medical students, improved rural training at Mount Isa and Broken Hill and general practice retention payments. All these things are designed to entice people to go into regional and rural areas.
