subdebateinfo.title: National Rugby League: South Sydney Rugby League Club

talk.start.para: âThe decision by the National Rugby League to exclude South Sydney from the 2000 competition leaves the faceless men who run the game with red and green blood on their hands. It is a fatal blow which will be challenged in every arenaâin the courts, in the parliament and in the public arena. The public know that this struggle is not just about South Sydney; it is about community, it is about history, it is about the aspirations of our youth and it is about whether the dollar can override all human and social relationships. Friday's decision is wrong. As Alan Jones has said:

speech.para: No country, no institution and no organisation can sweep history aside, without debate, without losing the support of those who have made that history and cherished that tradition.
It is wrong not just because it does not acknowledge the history of the game; it is wrong because it does not stand up to scrutiny.

The whole process was not public and the criteria were designed to achieve the outcome of payback to traditional clubs. There was an extraordinary decision to have two criteria. The basic criterion, which included junior development, ground facilities and solvency, was replaced by the ranking criterion. I will talk about just one of the criteria released last Fridayâprofitability. On the one hand, clubs like Canberra, North Queensland, Cronulla, Auckland and Melbourne have amassed massive debt with News Ltd. In two years Melbourne has amassed $12 million worth of debt. Their success on the field has been funded by massive debt, which contributes to other criteria such as crowd numbers. That is why South Sydney have asked for all the books of all these clubs to be open to public scrutiny. Compare this with Souths, who have paid their own way, have still been competitive and have still produced the most outstanding young prospect in rugby league in Craig Wing. To complete the farce, the $1.5 million grant from Souths Juniorsâmore than any club gives any team, junior or seniorâwas not taken into account in the criteria.

This crisis derives from the Super League assault in 1995. Super League paid too much for its players in a predatory pricing policy which could only have been justified if the game had become truly global. That has, of course, not been the case, and News Ltd have lost up to half a billion dollars through this exercise in just four years. So, if we talk about profitability of the clubs as being grounds for dismissal, News Ltd should be dismissed from their involvement in rugby league due to their financial mismanagement of their involvement. News Ltd have in fact won the war. The clubs which have been folded or forced to amalgamate are clubs which stayed loyal to the Australian Rugby League. Rugby league has lost some of its body parts during this war but it cannot survive if it has no soul. A scorched earth policy does not make sense. Rugby league is the loser if the product loses value and, as the major financial shareholder, News Ltd have an interest in the profitability and thriving of rugby league.

There are two options now before those who run the game: a dreadful, drawn-out fight for survival from Souths supporters over their right to play or News Ltd and the National Rugby League could gain enormous public support and kudos from simply backing off and saying, `We have heard the message of the public. Enough is enough. We will support South Sydney's right to play.' The game is not about elitesâquite the opposite. It is about the juniors and it is about the mums and dads who sell raffle tickets and cakes so their kids can play. Indeed, rugby league's greatest shareholder is not Rupert Murdoch; it is the fans, and that cannot be forgotten.

South Sydney have had magnificent leadership from George Piggins, who has led the way he played: with honour, with integrity, with courage, with determination and with principle. The respect he has from his community, who proudly proclaim `In George we trust', is a commodity which cannot be bought, it can only be earned. As he said about the failure of NRL Chairman Malcolm Noad to even phone him last Friday with the result, `We haven't got much money compared with them, but we've got more class.'

talk.start.para: âI would like to report to the parliament tonight about Australia's garrison city. Of course, I refer to Townsville. Over the past several weeks there has been enormous activity in that city in supporting the events in East Timor. Both at RAAF Townsville and at Lavarack Barracks tremendous amounts of work have been going on by members of the ADF who work at the local airfield and at the army barracks. I was at both the army barracks and the airfield last Friday. It is truly amazing the work that has been going on. RAAF Garbutt is a mass of tents. You could not put another tent there. The tents are there because of all the troops from other countries. On Friday there were Thai, Korean and Italian people there and also people from the USA.

speech.para: The logistics of handling all that have been horrendous. While from time to time things go wrong, I have not heard a single complaint. I am, of course, very close to the ADF in Townsville and I have not heard a single complaint. The troops there just get on, solve the problems and support our people in Timor.

Some of the warts when you have an extra 3,000 people on the base at any given time are how you handle the ablutions, the catering and the electricity supply. RAAF Townsville, under the command of Wing Commander Chris McHugh, has just gone in there and done the job. Interestingly, I think that the RAAF base has captured every last port-a-loo in North Queensland. They are all at the RAAF base, in addition to other temporary facilities.

The Commercial Support Program that has been introduced into the forces has by and large worked well, except in catering, and this is a little concerning. I think that when this is all over the ADF will look into this and perhaps rethink what they might do in relation to the Commercial Support Program and its relationship to catering, because clearly in this exercise it has not worked properly. I think that members of the ADF will back what I am saying here tonight.

Lavarack Barracksâwhich, of course, is home to the ready deployment force, the 1st Battalion of the Royal Australian Regiment and the 2nd Battalion of the Royal Australian Regimentâis almost like a ghost town. About 2,000 people have moved out of the barracks and gone to Timor. We have lost the 2nd Battalion. We have lost 10th Force Support Battalion. We have lost 3/4 Cavalry Regiment. We have lost 4th Field Regiment, and we have lost 3rd BASB. It is quite remarkable that there is only the 1st Battalion left. Of course, they are just itchingâin about February of next year when the rotation occursâto take their turn to go overseas.

Lieutenant Colonel Mark Bornholt of the 1st Battalion is certainly there making sure that his troops are ready to go. Of course they only just missed out on going because they had come off being the online battalion only about two or three weeks before this incident happened. The 2nd Battalion were very lucky. They became the online battalion, the battalion that responds within 24 hours, and they got to go. I know that they were very pleased and the 1st Battalion members were very disappointed. But they will have their go.

I am also pleased about the military band that is part of the 1st Battalion. There were some people down south who decided that Townsville was not going to have a military band, after some 30 years. Our city saw things differently to those down south, and I am pleased to say that the 1st Battalion band is likely also to go to Timor. It is going to be expanded rather than closed down and sent south.

Finally, I would like to compliment Margaret Kilin and her people at the Defence Community Organisation, who are supporting the families that are still in Townsville while the troops are overseas. Well done, Margaret, and well done to your team.

talk.start.para: âI rise in this adjournment debate to refer to seven local persons from my electorate of Greenway who have each received appropriate publicity in the local papers for service to my electorate, and whose input I acknowledge in these comments.

speech.para: Firstly, I refer to star Air League cadet William Tarbuck, a student at Tindale Christian School. William joined the Air League about nine years ago and has a major interest in aviation. He saw an Air League display at the Blacktown Festival, and this spurred him on to join this fine body. William has been flying since he was 16 and earned his pilots licence at 17. Once he finishes his HSC this year, he plans to work full time to enable him to raise sufficient money to pay for more flying lessons. I am advised that William went through a very hectic and stressful day of judging against competitors from all over the state to win this prestigious award of Cadet of the Year. Congratulations to William Tarbuck.

The dux of St Andrew's College, Marayong, Tadeusz Gielas, is a young man of Polish descent. He could not speak English when he arrived in Australia only seven years ago. I am advised that he learned English with such speed that he won the regional division of the Sydney Morning Herald's Young Writer of the Year competition in August. Tadeusz hopes to study law at university next year and is very busy preparing for the HSC, which begins shortly. He has chosen humanity subjects for his HSCânot the usual route to high UAI through science. We all wish him every success. Tadeusz's achievement again underlines our very successful migration system, which serves Australia so well.

My third comment is about St Johns Primary School, Riverstone student Sarah Procopio, who claimed a very creditable third place in the recent Voice of Youth competition finals. This annual event is designed to foster confidence and the ability to speak publicly among schoolchildren in the Parramatta diocese. Sarah spoke from the point of view of a Kosovo refugee and asked people to picture the anger and pain they would experience if they were forced to flee from their homes and split from their families, many of whom they would never see again. This is an important subject and a fine contribution from a young constituent who deserves high praise for her great effort.

A young man who is a resident of Blacktown, Francis Ocampo, believes the misrepresentation of Blacktown youth has been removed by the emergence of our young talented people. Francis has been selected to represent Australia in the Hague International Model United Nations Youth Conference in January of next year. He is one of 14 who beat 200 others from Australia and New Zealand. The process took about nine months to complete. The representatives were selected for their oratory and debating skills, confidence and closeness with the youth of Australia. Also needed were good academic results and active participation in sport. Francis Ocampo is greatly honoured by his selection, and he and his family are busy raising the $5,0000 needed to attend the conference.

Four students from Marsden Park Public School have beaten the best in Sydney's west to earn them the right to represent the region in a New South Wales school debating competition. Sharnie Hoskin, Christine Bruckner, Paula Bujega and Clayton Hood defeated Blaxland East Public School to win the final. The topic of the debate was `We are not a nation of imitators'.

As the parliament will see from my reference to these seven young people, Western Sydneyâand the Greenway electorate in particularâwill have no problem holding its head high as we move into the year 2000 with such fine young talented potential leaders within our great community. I salute them all, and I am confident that they will make their respective marks within our world in the years ahead.

subdebateinfo.title: Ballarat Electorate: Online Australia Field Day

talk.start.para: âDuring the grievance debate, I was referring to some events in my home town of Ballarat, and I would like to finish from where I left off, as time got away. During the grievance debate I was telling honourable members about an upcoming event in Ballarat of enormous significance to regional Victoria, and that is the Online Australia Field Day to be held on 19 and 20 November. It has been organised by the Centre for Electronic Commerce and Communications at the University of Ballarat.

speech.para: The field day has been modelled on successful agricultural field days and will have a rural focus. Attractions include field demonstrations showing the use of online technology in rural operations; a business expo; activities for children, including a kids tent with Internet, online learning and games; and a cyber cafe where visitors can order their food and drink online or surf the Net. Four main pavilions will offer participants the chance to learn hands-on, using interactive displays and computer equipment. I would like to congratulate Helen Dawes and Ross Davey from the Centre for Electronic Commerce and Communications, who have worked extremely hard to make the event the success that it will be.

Interestingly, this event underscores what is becoming increasingly apparent to all Australians, especially those living in rural and remote areas, about the need for those living outside metropolitan Melbourne, Sydney and the other capitals to have access to technology that others take for granted. I am absolutely convinced that, until rural and regional Australians do have that access, they will continue to suffer the impediments that are faced at the moment. The government is quite rightly putting tens of millions of dollars into the technology going into rural and regional areas. I would encourage the government to continue doing so and to renew their endeavours.

The important aspect is that the sale of 16 per cent of Telstra will actually deliver real benefits to regional and rural Australians. This is about transferring a part of the public ownership of an asset like Telstra back to the people. I do not hear many arguments from people in my electorate about the transfer of those funds back into regional and rural communities. It should not matter whether you live in Avoca or Adelaide, or Ballan or Brisbane, or Stawell or Sydney: you should have access to those basic services.

It was only a matter of two or three years ago that there were people in my electorate who could not access the poisons information line. So we really have some significant steps to take to make sure that the access is there. I think this country will finally have arrived when it does not matter where you live you are able to access that sort of technology, and you should be able to operate just as effectively on top of Ayers Rock as you would in a major capital city.

I think we are getting there. This government deserves congratulations in relation to where that money is going. My own University of Ballarat is very actively involved right throughout Western Victoria, taking information to farmers and to small business organisations right throughout my electorate and into the electorates of the honourable members for Wannon and Mallee. I think we are kicking some real goals, but we need to continue doing that. If we do, I think the access that regional and rural Australians and regional and rural Victorians and my constituents deserve will be delivered.

On one final matter in the short time that is left, I want to quickly go through some names in relation to the Australian Ex-POW Memorial Subcommittee. They are David Baird, Bill Bahr, Neville Greenbank, Barry Edwards, Bob Fewster, Les Kennedy, Frank Peebles, John Wilkinson, David van den Brule, Keith Bootsman, Mark Waddington, Rex Hollioak, Peter Blizzard, Phil Horwood, Ray Wheeler, Bill Toon, Jack Fitzgerald and John Paterson. These are the people who have got the memorial up and running, and they deserve the applause of this House.

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to rise today to support the member for Grayndlerânot in relation to his football club, although I wish him well in his endeavours, but concerning the Aviation Noise Ombudsman Bill 1999 . For the past year I have spent considerable time dealing with issues concerning the Perth airport. Members might recall my statements in this House pertaining to the plight of those residents affected by aircraft noise. The issues raised related to problems for the local community and for me as their representative.

speech.para: The first was the degree of community consultation that needed improvement, and the second was the capacity of the minister to take unilateral action in the face of community resistance to the plans of Westralia Airports Corporation. The decision making process can be illustrated by the intense community lobbying on the part of the residents of South Guildford, Cannington, Queens Park and their local government representatives, with respect to the noise problem. This has been echoed to a degree by other local issues, such as the recent proposed development of a car auction yard on Westralian Airports Corporation land, and other areas being used for industrial purposes. This development unfortunately created concerns with local residents. In many ways it was the methodology rather than the proposal that had residents up in arms. From my dealings with the residents, I can attest that many had constructive points of view to put, but they were ignored in the process.

I wish to indicate that I do not intend to castigate the Westralian Airports Corporation for its utilisation of resources at its disposal, rather for the way in which these decisions were made, which has had little regard for the views of residents or even standard planning considerations. Put quite simply, in signing off the Airports Draft Master Plan without a framework that would ensure fair and representative decision making, the government was asking for trouble. By supporting this bill, the government can send the message to the community that it cares about the impacts of airports on the community and that it is prepared to listen to them.

The role of the Ombudsman would be to process community complaints that would go to an independent body. This body will investigate breaches on behalf of those citizens. In doing so, the Ombudsman would remove the financial and political interests that may exist when solving the many contro versial matters and other issues associated with the operation of airports.

The benefits of the Aviation Noise Ombudsman Bill 1999 will ensure that complaints regarding excessive aircraft noise and flight paths are heard without bias and judged fairly on the merits of the case. An arm's-length approach is what is needed rather than the existing situation of complaining to the body which is itself responsible for those breaches. As we have seen in the case of Perth airport, this can lead to a feeling of alienation within the community. The increase in population around airports in Australia means that the government must take action.

In reading the documentation associated with the master plan in Perth I notice that as flight frequency increases approximately 10,000 local residents will be affected in the coming years. We certainly should plan now for the most appropriate mechanism to guarantee they are given the forum necessary to ensure that policy on the matter is hijacked by neither those with vested interests or those who consider the community views unimportant. We do need an independent referee who will enable people to achieve justice and have their complaints heard. I would also suggest that the creation of an independent body will mean that effective consultation occurs in the first place.

On a totally different tack, I also take this opportunity to congratulate Steve Bracks and his Labor government in Victoria. Well done. I am hoping that we can achieve the same result in Western Australia with Geoff Gallop and his team next year.

talk.start.para: âI wish to draw the attention of the House and indeed of the Australian community to a video recording of an interactive drug forum which I was privileged to be able to hold in my electorate of Bradfield on 17 August this year. It was sponsored by the Bradfield Liberal Party, the Rotary Club of Lindfield, Sony Music Australia and RAMS. It was unique in the sense that it brought together a range of people with a different perspective and expertise, including Professor David Bennett, the head of the Department of Adolescent Medicine at the Children's Hospital in Sydney; Ms Imogen Clark, who is the author of Saving Jesse , in which she recounts her family's experiences dealing with their daughter's addiction to heroin; Mr Martin Enock, who is the president of the St Ives High School P&C; and Ms Sally Loane, the Radio 2BL presenter and the author of Who cares? Guilt, hope and the child care debate ; Lieutenant Paul Moulds, the director of the Oasis Youth Network for the Salvation Army; Dr Ian Paterson, who concluded 28 years as the principal of Knox Grammar late last year; Mr Tony Trimmingham, who of course founded Family Drug Support, initiated after the death of his son Damien in 1997 from a heroin overdose; Dr Alex Wodak, the Director of Alcohol and Drug Services for St Vincent's Hospital; and two year 11 students.

speech.para: The forum was provocative and also confronting at times. I have now addressed, I would think, hundreds of drug forums over the years. I have found many of them to have limited value. I have either been asked to give quite powerful dissertations on the evils of smoking cannabis or I have gone along to be seen to be offering support to those who want to unravel the policies of prohibition.

What we did on this occasion, over two hours, was cover the issues of not only the drugs themselves but also what parents do if they find that one of their children is using drugsâwhich, sadly, is more likely to be the case than not, these days. We talked about the challenges of adolescence; drugs in schools; drug use as a normal part of growing up, if you like; teenage parties; drug education; every parent's nightmare, the addiction of a son or daughter to heroinâin this case, one ended in death and the other in hope. We discussed `What would I do differently if I could go back?' We also examined the issues of injecting rooms, heroin trials and the use of cannabis.

A couple of remarkable comments were made during the interactive evening. For example, in the debate about injecting rooms, Lieutenant Paul Moulds, who runs the Youth Oasis program for the Salvation Army, put quite a compelling argument for why he considers that injecting rooms and heroin trials would perhaps send messages to young people that we are liberalising our attitudes to these drugs. I then invited him to present those views directly to Mr Trimmingham, whose son died not only because he used heroin but because he injected alone and died from an overdose. Trimmingham said, in defence of his view that there ought to be injecting rooms, `Look, I admire everything the government is doing. I admire everything the Salvation Army is doing. But you can't save the life of somebody who is already dead.'

Ms Imogen Clark discussed going back over the years to when she first discovered that her daughter was using cannabis and subsequently heroin. She said, `I would be much more proactive about the way I talk to my kids about drugsâmore explicit, more direct. There are some issues for kids that no school can deal with.'
The ABC presenter and author, Sally Loane said:
Some parents have no faith in their ability to bring up children. If you don't talk to them and listen to them right from the start, by the time they're 13 it is too late.

The President of St Ives P&C said, when I asked him, that of the 1,200 parents in their school population less than five per cent actually are members of the P&C and only one per cent of that school population of parents actually turn up to meetings.

I urge anyone who has an interest in the complexities surrounding drug use and the things that drive it to acquire a copy of this video, if they wish, from my office. I think parents, schools and young people in particular would find it particularly helpful. We hear a lot about the problems of drug use; we hear much less about the solutions. Perhaps this might in some way contribute to a better understanding of them.
